segments.text: Well, can I talk?
Sure.
OK.
So I really enjoyed visiting in their home.
I remember when I first met Hannah, they adopted her after they came here.
And so there she was.
And she's a real sweet person.
In fact,
At that occasion, it also happened that Harlan's dissertation advisors, Cecilia Payne-Gaposchkin and Sergei, were visiting the family at that time.
Oh, that must have been interesting.
That was very interesting, because Sergei was telling all about his escape across the Black Sea after the revolution, and landing in Turkey.
He had some strange ideas about Turkish language, which I knew were wrong, but I let him know.
persistent as Polly, so to speak.
Do you think, I think we'll probably all agree that Harlan is not what the general public expects from an observatory director in appearance, right?
Do you think that in Texas, though, he's considered now?
Oh, well, he fit into the Texas lifestyle quite easily, apparently.
If you just take a look at all the people in Texas who seem to have had a high regard for Harlan,
He knew how to get along with people, and he knew how to get them interested in astronomy, get them interested in what the observatory was doing.
He was really great in that regard.
Let me ask you first a question pertaining to you.
you meet people and tell them what you do, what do they think?
I mean, do they think astronomers are sponging off productive elements, or do they think it's a neat job?
I have very seldom had a reaction such as you describe.
Usually it's, oh, how interesting.
And when I tell them about Hubble, they say, oh, well, what went wrong?
Or, oh, yeah.
But there's clearly a lot of interest in astronomy as astronomy.

You know, people I've talked to on the planes, I'll get a picture or an article, they'll send me in the mail, you know, some insurance executive or what have you will say, this I thought you'd be interested in this.
Because of course I give them my card, because that's how one does it, right?
Exchange cards here, Ron?
Okay.
That's the cheapest form of advertisement that there is.
Occasionally there'll be somebody who couldn't care less, but that's not the usual reaction.
I ask that because one time I was trapped on a plane with Shirley MacLaine's advance lady.
Oh dear.
That was a difficult four hours.
Well, you know, it's the sort of thing that I'm not going to justify astronomy on the basis of all the things that it does for mankind.
It satisfies people's curiosity, and I think that's really its justification.
Now, I've been asking this about planetary astronomy, but it applies in two other ways.
One is the University of Texas Astronomy Department, and astronomers generally in this country
There's no question that McDonald's and UT Austin have sold themselves well in this state.
And, well, really, through Stardate, that's what people in Boston think of.
They never heard.
I don't know if UT has a medical school or a law school or anything.
Probably don't care that it has a football team, but they know Stardate.
But do you think American astronomers have sold as well as they have in Texas?
As well as?
What should they be doing?
I don't know.
I mean, this is personal opinion stuff, but I want to lighten up the book with some stuff.
I really don't know how to answer that question.
I've been asking everyone, this is their one chance, what do you think is the most important work you've done so far?
They're going to carve something on your tombstone.
Well, I...
Keeping the astrometry team going through all the thick and thin of this problems that the telescope has had from the very beginning, I think, has been important.
And finally starting to get some results.
It's been the hardest thing that I've ever done, to put it that way.
In terms of ultimate value to science, it's hard to say because we've
still have our results to get.
If we discover a planet around some star, that would be very interesting.
That's a roll of the dice kind of situation.
Some of my earlier stuff, well, I've done some interesting work in statistics in connection with the space telescope work, in fact.
We have a very interesting computer program, which we developed, that really makes doing least squares problems extremely easy.
Oh, well that sounds like a great boom to mankind.
And it's got, there have been a lot of people, you know, that have been using it, and with profit.
You can imagine, it's got, I mean, you can apply it to all sorts of things.
So I'm kind of proud of that work.
And the other things that have been sort of a cumulative thing, I don't know if there's any particular one paper that I could point to in some of my work on celestial mechanics.
But taken together, I think that there's a lot of interesting research there.
What do you think is going to happen to planetary astronomy, celestial mechanics, that sort of stuff now that budgets have leveled off or are decreasing?
Well, celestial mechanics doesn't need a whole lot of money.
in the sense that you need access to a computer primarily.
Most of the interesting research is being done by massaging, you know, running computer programs these days.
Well, I mean, I'm talking particularly here about are you still encouraging graduate students to enter the field or not?
I encourage people to enter fields that they have interest in.
I don't
I've never, you know, either encouraged or discouraged a student from going into a particular area of astronomy or into astronomy itself based on whether or not they'll find a job at the end of it.
I think that if you're good, there'll be a job.
And the only way to find out if you're good is to try it and see.
So I've had
Several graduate students, they all have jobs at the moment.
Gene Bird and Bob Harrington was my student also.
I was going to say, I didn't mention this, but my grandfather had been a doctor in China from 1900 to
Now there's some conflict about this, whether it was 1911 or 1913 that he came back.
My father always said 1913, but his older sister, who's still alive, Adelaide, said that it was 1911.
So probably it was 1911.
Interesting years in China.
Right.
This was just after the Boxer Revolution and just up until the 1911 revolution.

Anyhow, because of that China connection, and also because of the connection with my mother's roommate in college who had also grown up, been born and grown up in China, and three of my aunts born and grown up in China, or at least partly grown up in China,
and going to my grandfather's house and seeing all these wonderful Chinese chinoiserie and stuff like that that he brought back with him.
I have always been interested in China, studied Chinese when I was in college, studied it some more when I got here.
And so that was yet another connection with Joan and Harlem, which I always was very fond of.
Now, I know Harlan took a trip, at least, well, I remember the first one he took to China's Jonestown back there.
Okay.
Harlan went to China in, was it 77 or 78?
That was the first trip of all the official astronomers.
Schwarzschild went on the trip.
All these other people went on the trip.
Harlan was on that trip.
Harlan and Joan went to China.
And Joan will have to tell you when, but they did go to China, I think twice.
Once in the mid-'80s.
Because I remember him showing us pictures of this long, red colonnade garden, what do you call it?
Gallery or something.
And Joan used to play there as a kid.
But they went there a second time, and I think it was like mid-'80s.
And then they went there.
No, it would be 1990.
They didn't go in 1989.
They'd been thinking of going, but then Tiananmen happened.
So I think they went the following year.
That last trip, they climbed Tai Shan, or Mount Tai.
which is a famous, one of the three famous sacred mountains in China.
Is that the one where the two provinces are, east of the mountain and west of the mountain, you know, Shantan and Shaanxi?
It could be.
It could be.
I'm not certain about that.
Joan would know.
I have not been to Taishan.
But it is, it's a famous pilgrimage site.
And, of course, during, for a long time people weren't going to it because, you know, one wasn't supposed to practice religion.
Now that they've eased up on certain practices of religion,
although China is still, you know, a totalitarian country, and one has to watch what one says.
Nevertheless, people now do go in great numbers to that place.
They climbed the mountain, as I understand, while they were there.
So she has been there.
She has been to her childhood home in China,
I think it's Changsha.
I think Changsha is where it was, but Joan will tell you about that.
And in fact, I visited my grandfather's home in Shanghai when I was there the last time.
Because, again, this is one of these funny things.
I was at friends' meeting one day.
Joan Smith was there.
After the rise of meeting, Joan was talking with an elderly lady
And she, I went over and it turned out they were talking about China.
And it turned out that this lady had been born in Shanghai.
And I said, oh, well, you know, three of my aunts were born in Shanghai.
And she said, oh, well, who were they?
And I said, well, I don't think you probably know them.
Oh, well, I didn't know at that time how well connected all these old China people were.
I said, well, they're, you know, Jeffries was the name.
Oh, she said, I grew up in the Jeffries house.
And she had in fact, her father had in fact taken my grandfather's job after my grandfather came back from China for health reasons.
And so she knew where the house was.
She had been to that house.
She sent me detailed instructions on how to find it.
Her name was Alice Walker.
She lives in Hawaii or did it the last time I wrote her.
And so she
and enabled me to find this house, which is now a school in the old hospital compound.
There's too many coincidences in this world.
Isn't it?
It's amazing.
Let me tell you a story that doesn't have anything to do with China, but it has to.
